channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report X-2024010791
item.description:
Report X-2024010791

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-07T15:11:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-26
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Box was found wet inside of a plastic bag in the QA damage area. Content is an Everstart Maxx Group 35 battery. Label on package is a customer return label to Walmart. DescribePack: Upon inspection, battery was not actively leaking. Some cracks were seen on top. A test strip was applied to the wet box and showed to be in the PH 0-1 range. Therefore, the moisture is believed to be battery acid from within. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Leakage was not spreading. Battery was kept in upright position during examination.

item.title: Report E-2024020063
item.description:
Report E-2024020063

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-07T15:11:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-29
  • City: MILWAUKEE
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 29, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of isopropanol was damaged in transit due to a load strap failure and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews overpacked the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 85-gallon salvage drum. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the released product and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents, any cleanup debris, and PPE were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

item.title: Report X-2024010749
item.description:
Report X-2024010749

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-07T15:11:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-04
  • City: MIDDLETOWN
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Shipment taken out of system flow due to external carton wet. Upon inspection of inner contents 4 X 1 gallon plastic bottles Sizzle scale remover. 1 X 1 gallon plastic bottle of Sizzle scale remover had a loose cap allowing 1 gallon to release. The other 3 X 1 gallon plastic bottles were soiled/damaged. There was a slotted partition and each individual plastic bottle was in a plastic bag but no absorbent was found. All contents inside package was damaged. Facility procedures for damaged hazardous materials followed. Contents contained and awaiting disposition. DescribePack: 1 X 1 gallon of Sizzle scale remover had a loose cap leaking out all contents soiling/damaging the other 3 X 1 gallon plastic bottles. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Hazmat package was placed inside a hazmat bag lined red tote.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-27
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN ANCHORAGE, ALASKA ONE PACKAGE GOING TO HONG KONG WAS INSPECTED DUE TO A DESCRIPTION ON THE THERMAL TRACKING LABEL OF CAR BATTERY JUMP STARTER. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TWO JUMP STARTERS BOTH PACKAGED IN INNER PACKAGING WITH PREPRINTED UN3480 LITHIUM BATTERY MARKS. WHITE OPAQUE WRAPPING SURROUNDS THE OUTER BOX WITHOUT ANY DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON TOP OF THE OPAQUE WHITE WRAPPING. UNDER THE WHITE OPAQUE WRAPPING IS A FIBERBOARD BOX WITH AN APPLIED UN3480 LITHIUM BATTERY MARK. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER FB2840, ENSON MARKET, 2131 PLEASANT HILL RD., DULUTH GA 30096-2321.

  • Description: A DANGEROUS GOODS DECLARED PACKAGE THAT HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACLITY IN THE USA WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING IN THE UNITED KINGDOM. THE PACKAGE IS PROPERLY PREPARED AS UN3363, DANGEROUS GOODS IN APPARATUS WITH AN APPROPRIATE IATA SHIPPERS DECLARATION, CLASS 9 DIAMOND LABEL AND ORIENTATION ARROWS. INNER CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS AN AIRCRAFT PART ENCLOSED AND ZIPTIED WITHIN A PLASTIC BAG. THERE IS A SMALL PUNCTURE IN THE BAG CONSISTENT WITH THE SHAPE OF THE PART INSIDE THE BAG. THE OUTER FIBERBOARD BOX HAS ALSO BEEN PUNCTURED SLIGHTLY CONSISTENT TO THE SAME COMPROMISED LOCATION. PAPERWORK INSIDE THE PACKAGE INDICATES THE PRODUCT AS "8120-2 FUEL OIL COOLER OIL LEAK FTN 5M3095". THE INVOICE AND THERMAL LABEL DESCRIPTION OF THE COMMODITY IS A COOLER. PRIOR TO THE LEAKING DISCOVERY THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT FROM ATL TO SDF AND SDF TO PHL TO EMA.

Upon inspection two of the six acetone containers were dented and leaking. DescribePack: The package itself had no rips or tears. The containers inside were dented, causing the leaking. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The leaking was contained to the inside of the package and only mishandling had the items leaking more. No absorbent was needed to mitigate the release only careful handling.

Inner contents: 2 glass bottles at approximately 1 Liter each, separately wrapped in cushioning/absorbent pads inside plastic barrier bags. There was no release of the contents. The shipment is being held for FAA investigation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: FRA Hazmat Inspector Wolfe reported the TILX 306907 releasing an unknown amount of vapor. UP Hazmat responded to the car. Upon inspecting the car, the valve handles were able to be turned very slightly indicating they were in an open position. The valve plugs were impacted with several layers of old teflon tape and thread dope which prohibited the plugs from being fully engaged and secured. There was also old teflon debris inside of the valve body and threaded faceplate. The handles were all closed, and the plugs were removed and cleaned. The debris was also removed from the valve body. New teflon tape was applied to the threads and the plugs were secured tool tight.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 1/5/2024, at approximately 1400, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 240946 at the station location in Spokane, reporting an undeclared battery sihpment. The package contains an electric lawnmower, powered by lithium battery. The package was orginally tendered with a UN 3481 marked on the package. The shipment was rejected and the shipper was contracted for retrieval. The shipper returned the shipment with the previous marking partially crossed out and declared the shipment unregulated. Further investigation confirmed that the contents inside was indeed an electric lawnmover, packed with a lithium battery. The shipment was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations. The shipment is being held, pending an investgation by the FAA.

  • Description: The tank car had a prior release while being switched in the yard because the pressure relief device broke and fell into the car on Dec17, 2023 (5800 report # 2023121166). The Haz Mat manager Tom Robinson put the car into a hold and told the yard manager to not move the car until a new valve was put onto the car. There was a bag applied to the missing PRD to protect the commodity. The car was moved to Englewood Yard and then back to Settegast where it was reported to be leaking again to Haz Mat manager Tom Robinson. During movement the product sloshed out underneath the bag that was covering the broken PRD. The car was set back onto the track it was originally in, and the Haz Mat Manager was assured it would not move again until the proper repairs made.

  • Description: Enviroserve was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 5ft-by-2ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that one (1) gallon of material was released due to a puncture into one (1) 330-gallon plastic tote. Enviroserve personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and recovered the spent material and placed it into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The remaining product in the damaged tote was transferred to a new tote and the damaged plastic tote was cut-up and placed into the previously mentioned 55-gallon poly tote and one additional 95-gallon poly drum. The new plastic tote was shipped onto the consignee and the generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 26, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum containing UN3266 was crushed in transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel neutralized the corrosive impacted trailer using a water and citric acid solution. After the dock trailer floor was neutralized, crews deployed granular absorbent to the impacted trailer. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The 55-gallon drum was overpacked into one 95-gallon poly drum. All waste was then driven to the R+L terminal in Elgin, IL to be staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: A Veolia employee was moving a pallet of drums onto a trailer using a forklift at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility in Kansas City. There was a slight bump as he was driving onto the trailer which resulted in one of the drums falling off the pallet being carried by the forklift. The drum had an older ring on the lid which broke as a result of the fall. Approximately 2 pounds of the waste inside the drum spilled onto the trailer floor. The spill was contained inside the trailer, was immediately cleaned up and the team replaced the ring and lid for the drum with a new one.

item.title: Report E-2024010520
item.description:
Report E-2024010520

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-02T15:12:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-25
  • City: Brewster
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wheeling and Lake Erei Railway
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: I, John Vergis Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE, was called by the WLE Brewster Yardmaster at 0130 hrs. on 1-25-2024 for a report of leaking tank car GATZX 80031. When I arrived to look at the car, I noticed that the car was leaking from the breadbox cover. I removed seal #0000823 and opened the lid to find that the leak was coming from the Apollo Liquid Valve. I saw that the valve stem nut was backed off the stem and that the valve handle was not secured tight to the stem anymore. It looked like when someone tried to tighten the valve, that is did not close all the way because the valve handle did not fit properly since it was loose. I applied the handle back on the stem and tried closing the valve. The valve did then close and the leak stopped. The liquid was leaking from out of the valve plug which was not tight. I tried to tighten the valve stem nut but I could not get it to tighten. I backed off the nut completely and found that someone tried installing a course thread nut onto a fine thread valve stem. That is why the nut would not tighten down onto the handle. I then tried installing a fine thread nut and I was able to get it to tighten down. I felt that is was a good fix. I then removed the plug from the valve since it was leaking and found that there was no thread tape on the threads that were screwed into the valve. There was a build up of old tape on the top portion of the threads but not on the threads that would actually seal. Installed new thread sealant and tightened the valve plug. I then closed the breadbox lid and inatalled new seal #0000229. I then released the car for transportation.

item.title: Report X-2024010075
item.description:
Report X-2024010075

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-06T18:12:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-23
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 12-23-2023 a CN transportation employee observed liquid dripping from the bottom outlet valve cap during routing work operations at the CN Waterloo Yard in Waterloo, IA. The employee notified the Yard Supervisor who then initiated an emergency response from the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The responding DG Officer observed liquid dripping from the BOV cap which was found to be tool tight (could not turn by hand). The shipper's security seal was not found. BOV handle was in the fully closed position. It was determined that there was a failure in the sealing surface of the valve seat to include a defective or missing BOV gasket. The BOV handle was cycled several times from the closed to open position to ensure there was no foreign material trapped in the valve seat that would prevent a proper seal. The cap was then removed, and the valve was monitored for 10 minutes for any continued leakage. There was no longer any leakage from the valve at this point. An inspection of the BOV cap gasket was performed and revealed it to be very stiff allowing the product to leak past the gasket. The BOV gasket was replaced, and the cap re-installed utilizing a 24" pipe wrench.

  • Description: Driver reached out due to having issues when trying to offload. Safety determined there was a leak on top of the trailer, and it wouldnt build pressure. Safety told the driver to stop what she was doing and reached out to another driver close by to see if he could assist, then called the AMLO terminal. They found there was a check valve failure, and it wouldnt close. They also found the trailer didnt have some of the fittings needed and the other driver supplied them. Bleeder fitting was on the other end at customers connection instead of truck side. Driver couldnt connect it to truck side due to not having the correct fittings so she connected to customers end connection before it goes into the building. When Driver went to open an ear on the fitting, it sprayed out, and they didnt realize pressure was on the hose. Customer mentioned it was water soluble and sprayed down concrete with water and the drivers chemical suits. Driver mentions that after talking with the customer, their valve was open on the inside of the building and their system had pressure on it causing to backflow into the truck hose. Customer closed valve inside building and both drivers drain what they could in the hoses and cap hoses. After the repair was completed on the vacuum breaker she went back to unload at customer.

item.title: Report E-2023120219
item.description:
Report E-2023120219

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-02T00:33:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-22
  • City: LIVINGSTON
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 11/22/2023, at approximately 13:51 hours, CSX train M54121 derailed at milepost 00C 138.8. As a result of the derailment two tank cars containing sulfur breached and released their contents which caught fire. Additionally, an empty tank car, which last contained methanol, was determined to have breached. Multiple other rail cars containing non-regulated materials also breached and released contents- some of which caught fire. The shippers of hazardous materials (loaded and residue shipments) were notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2023-11-22-00172). Multiple response contractors, as well as CSX Hazardous Materials Team personnel, were responded to the incident emergently. CSX and contractor personnel contained the fire and releases, as well as remediated the environmental impact. Due to air quality concerns from the fire, local responders recommended that residents in the area of the derailment site evacuate. This recommended evacuation applied to a single residence shortly after the derailment occurred and continued to expand for several hours until it included the entire town of Livingston, KY. On 11/23/2023, at 16:00 hours, response officials lifted the evacuation.

item.title: Report E-2024020013
item.description:
Report E-2024020013

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-06T00:30:58+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-22
  • City: CHILLICOTHE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS-NOLWOOD CHEMICALS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver was travelling east on US-50 near Chillicothe on a 2 lane highway, when an oncoming minivan swerved into his lane causing our driver to slam on his brakes resulting in a 22mph decrease in speed in one second. Driver was able to avoid the minivan and resumed his route going east on US-50. A few minutes later, a car flagged down our driver to have him pull over. It was then discovered that chemicals were leaking out of our trailer. Over a twelve hour period it was discovered that a load bar bracing a MEA tote went through the tote puncturing the tote to release all of its contents. All of the authorities required were immediately contacted, along with Clean Harbours dispatched to clean the spill of chemicals. The time of the incident was 7:52am, and the scene was finally cleared around 8pm that night.
